sentence: Once one of America's most shining retailers, JCPenney JCP has lost much of its luster over the past several years.
However, after a fourth-consecutive earnings beat, JCPenney has been added to the Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) list, and it appears the company's turnaround is in full swing.
Last week, JCPenney posted fourth-quarter fiscal 2015 earnings of 39 cents, which smashed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 22 cents.
The company's quarterly earnings also came in well ahead of last year's fourth quarter earnings of just four cents.
Also, revenues of $3.996 billion beat the consensus estimate of $3.989 billion and also represented growth of 2.6% on a year-over-year basis.
Comparable-store sales increased 4.1% from last year, with Home, Footwear, Handbags, and Sephora coming in as the company's best-performing categories.
Furthermore, gross profit in the fourth quarter improved 3.7% to $1.363 billion, with gross margin expanding 30 basis points to 34.1% due to improved margins on promotional and clearance sales.

JCPenney expects another strong year of profits and guided for an additional 3%-4% growth in comparable store sales, as well as a further increase in gross margin in the range of 40 to 60 basis points.
The company's resoundingly positive earnings report has had analysts in a frenzy, and we've seen two positive estimate upgrades for JCPenney's annual earnings within in the past seven days.
JCPenney's recent success is no accident-it's a result of a deliberate shift in corporate strategy that started when it hired former Home Depot HD exec Marvin Ellison as its CEO in October 2014.
Ellison quickly realized the importance of modernizing the company.
Internet-based commerce has devastated traditional brick and mortar retailers, and the online business shows no sign of slowing down.
In fact, according to Euromonitor International , internet retail grew 13% in the US alone last year.
Ellison detailed several ways in which JCPenney has modernized during last week's earnings conference call, including a new focus on social media marketing.
"As we all know, that's a more efficient way to communicate and it's less costly than traditional print or TV," Ellison said during the call.

The new CEO also explained the company's recent investment in its own leadership: "We went out and we recruited one of the best e-commerce executives in retail, we went out and recruited a great supply-chain executive, we just named a new chief information officer, we have a new marketing leader," Ellison told CNBC on Monday .
"The reason why we were so successful in the fourth quarter is because of the buy-in of the team to the strategy."
The company has also made more specific, store-level changes.
A new emphasis on promotions has been implemented, including the recent announcement of "Penney Days" where name-brand clothing items will sell for as little as one penny.
Furthermore, JCPenney has renewed its interest in private label brands, while also promising to redesign its own line of sunglasses, fashion jewelry, and accessories.
Ellison also promised that at least 60 new Sephora stores will open in 2016.
On top of this, JCPenney stores have begun selling appliances again, putting the retailer in competition with struggling rival Sears SHLD .
It's no surprise that JCPenney, which has seen its stock value cut in half over the past five years, decided to make massive changes from the top down.
What may be surprising to some, however, is how well it worked.
Of course, JCPenney hasn't earned its Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) ranking simply because of a change in corporate rhetoric.
Right now, it looks like both the numbers and the strategy are on JCPenney's side.
